title: Basic fmesher use
code: domain <- cbind(rnorm(4, sd = 3), rnorm(4)) (mesh2 <- fm_mesh_2d(   boundary = fm_extensions(domain, c(2.5, 5)),   max.edge = c(0.5, 2) )) #> fm_mesh_2d object: #>   Manifold:  R2 #>   V / E / T: 888 / 2622 / 1735 #>   Euler char.:   1 #>   Constraints:   39 boundary edges (1 group: 1), 115 interior edges (1 group: 1) #>   Bounding box: (-11.963110,  8.246925) x (-5.522181, 5.499657) x (0,0) #>   Basis d.o.f.:  888 plot(mesh2, axes = TRUE) (mesh1 <- fm_mesh_1d(   c(0, 2, 4, 7, 10),   boundary = "free", # c("neumann", "dirichlet"),   degree = 2 )) #> fm_mesh_1d object: #>   Manifold:  R1 #>   #{knots}:  5 #>   Interval:  ( 0, 10) #>   Boundary:  (free, free) #>   B-spline degree:   2 #>   Basis d.o.f.:  6

title: Basic fmesher use
code: pts <- cbind(rnorm(400, sd = 3), rnorm(400))  # Find what triangle each point is in, and it's triangular Barycentric coordinates bary <- fm_bary(mesh2, loc = pts) # How many points are outside the mesh? sum(is.na(bary$t)) #> [1] 2 head(bary$bary) #>            [,1]      [,2]      [,3] #> [1,] 0.04720217 0.5813611 0.3714367 #> [2,] 0.13950532 0.7212692 0.1392255 #> [3,] 0.43189448 0.1384910 0.4296145 #> [4,] 0.20031702 0.3721526 0.4275303 #> [5,] 0.21259133 0.3686084 0.4188003 #> [6,] 0.44390951 0.1739205 0.3821700  # Construct an evaluator object evaluator <- fm_evaluator(mesh2, loc = pts) sum(!evaluator$proj$ok) #> [1] 2  # Values for the basis function weights; for ordinary 2d meshes this coincides # with the resulting values at the vertices, but this is not true for e.g. # 2nd order B-splines on 1d meshes. field <- mesh2$loc[, 1] value <- fm_evaluate(evaluator, field = field) sum(abs(pts[, 1] - value), na.rm = TRUE) #> [1] 5.704812e-14 pts1 <- seq(-2, 12, length.out = 1000)  # Find what segment, and its interval Barycentric coordinates bary1 <- fm_bary(mesh1, loc = pts1) # Points outside the interval are treated differently depending on the # boundary conditions: sum(is.na(bary1$t)) #> [1] 0 head(bary1$bary) #>          [,1]      [,2] #> [1,] 2.000000 -1.000000 #> [2,] 1.992993 -0.992993 #> [3,] 1.985986 -0.985986 #> [4,] 1.978979 -0.978979 #> [5,] 1.971972 -0.971972 #> [6,] 1.964965 -0.964965  # Construct an evaluator object. evaluator1 <- fm_evaluator(mesh1, loc = pts1) # mesh_1d basis functions are defined everywhere sum(!evaluator1$proj$ok) #> [1] 0  # Values for the basis function weights; for ordinary 2d meshes this coincides # with the resulting values at the vertices, but this is not true for e.g. # 2nd order B-splines on 1d meshes. field1 <- rnorm(fm_dof(mesh1)) value1 <- fm_evaluate(evaluator1, field = field1) plot(pts1, value1, type = "l")

code: samp <- fm_matern_sample(mesh2, alpha = 2, rho = 4, sigma = 1)[, 1] evaluator <- fm_evaluator(mesh2, lattice = fm_evaluator_lattice(mesh2, dims = c(150, 50))) image(evaluator$x, evaluator$y, fm_evaluate(evaluator, field = samp), asp = 1)

title: The fmesher C++ library
text: mesh storage composed 3-column matrix vertex coordinates, S, three triangle graph topology 3-column integer matrices: TV: 3 vertex indices, CCW order TT: 3 corners, index opposing edge neighbouring triangle, , otherwise -1. TTi: 3 corners, -triangle index opposing edge’s neighbouring triangle’s opposing -triangle index. structure can turned /allow certain operations efficient. similar winged-edge half-edge structure, treats triangles primary objects, allowing compact storage well efficient graph traversal. Note: structure, VT, can enabled, vertex gives index single triangle used . limitation data structure cheap way access triangles connect given vertex, unless mesh proper edge-connected manifold. example, operation handle meshes forward inverse orbit0 operations reach connected triangles. handle cases, data structure may need extended triangle index set vertex, effect replacing VT single-index vector vector sets, replacing key algorithms currently rely orbit0 operations.

title: The fmesher C++ library
text: Dart location objects; originator vertex, edge direction, triangle alpha0: swap originating vertex edge, keep triangle alpha1: swap edge pointing remaining 3rd vertex, keep originator vertex triangle alpha2: swap adjacent triangle, stay along edge keep originator vertex orbit0 = alpha1,alpha2: move next CCW adjacent triangle, except boundary orbit1 = alpha2,alpha0: move adjacent triangle swap edge direction, except boundary orbit2 = alpha0,alpha1: move next CCW vertex triangle operators, inverses, allow arbitrary graph traversal 2-manifold meshes triangles connected via edges.

title: Converting legacy INLA mesh code to fmesher
text: Three INLA::inla.getOption()/INLA::inla.setOption() options control transition behaviour INLA package use fmesher. fmesher.evolution, integer: 1L uses intermediate fm_* methods fmesher already available via inlabru 2.8.0, calls INLA built-fmesher standalone programme mesh construction related operations. (INLA version 23.06.29) 2L uses full range fmesher package methods, use standalone fmesher programme. (INLA around version 23.08.20) fmesher.evolution.warn, logical: TRUE, INLA show deprecation methods methods INLA replaced fmesher package methods. FALSE, warnings shown. Set option TRUE want update code, keep FALSE need run existing code without changing . fmesher.evolution.verbosity, character: Either “soft”, “warn”, “stop”, indicating minimum warning level fmesher.evolution.warn TRUE. Set “warn” “stop” get immediate feedback testing conversion old code, e.g. package testing.

title: Triangle Meshes and Related Geometry Tools
text: Generate planar spherical triangle meshes, compute finite element calculations 1- 2-dimensional flat curved manifolds associated basis function spaces, methods lines polygons, transparent handling coordinate reference systems coordinate transformation, including ‘sf’ ‘sp’ geometries. core ‘fmesher’ library code originally part INLA package, also distributed EUSTACE Horizon 2020 project, implements parts “Triangulations Applications” Hjelle Dæhlen (2006). expanded crs/CRS support started add-feature inlabru.

longlat for a sphere of radius 1m print(fm_crs("longlat_norm")) #> Coordinate Reference System: #>   User input: +proj=longlat +R=1 +no_defs  #>   wkt: #> GEOGCRS["unknown", #>     DATUM["unknown", #>         ELLIPSOID["unknown",1,0, #>             LENGTHUNIT["metre",1, #>                 ID["EPSG",9001]]]], #>     PRIMEM["Reference meridian",0, #>         ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433, #>             ID["EPSG",9122]]], #>     CS[ellipsoidal,2], #>         AXIS["longitude",east, #>             ORDER[1], #>             ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433, #>                 ID["EPSG",9122]]], #>         AXIS["latitude",north, #>             ORDER[2], #>             ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433, #>                 ID["EPSG",9122]]]]  # title: Create a coordinate reference system object — fm_CRS
text: x Object convert CRS extract CRS information . oblique Vector length 4 rotation angles (degrees) oblique projection, values defaulting zero. values indicate (longitude, latitude, orientation, orbit), explained Details section fm_crs(). ... Additional parameters, passed sub-methods. projargs Either 1) projection argument string suitable input sp::CRS, 2) existing CRS object, 3) shortcut reference string predefined projection; run names(fm_wkt_predef()) valid predefined projections. (projargs compatibility parameter can used default fm_CRS() method) doCheckCRSArgs ignored. args optional list name/value pairs add /override PROJ4 arguments projargs.  name=value converted "+name=value", name=NA converted "+name". SRS_string WKT2 string defining coordinate system; see sp::CRS. takes precedence projargs.

title: Create a coordinate reference system object — fm_CRS
text: Either sp::CRS object inla.CRS object, depending coordinate reference system described parameters can expressed pure sp::CRS object . S3 inla.CRS object list, usually (necessarily) containing least one element: crs basic sp::CRS object

title: Create a coordinate reference system object — fm_CRS
text: first two elements oblique vector (longitude, latitude) coordinates oblique centre point. third value (orientation) counterclockwise rotation angle observer looking centre point outside sphere. fourth value quasi-longitude (orbit angle) rotation along oblique observers equator. Simple oblique: oblique=c(0, 45) Polar: oblique=c(0, 90) Quasi-transversal: oblique=c(0, 0, 90) Satellite orbit viewpoint: oblique=c(lon0-time*v1, 0, orbitangle, orbit0+time*v2), lon0 longitude satellite orbit crosses equator time=0, satellite angle orbit0 along orbit.  orbital angle relative equatorial plane orbitangle, v1 v2 angular velocities planet satellite, respectively. Note "forward" satellite's point view "right" projection. oblique[2] oblique[3] non-zero, resulting projection correct perfect spheres.

title: Blockwise aggregation matrices — fm_block
text: block integer vector; block information. NULL, rep(1L, block_len) used, block_len determined length(log_weights))) length(weights))). single scalar also repeated vector corresponding length weights. weights Optional weight vector log_weights Optional log(weights) vector. Overrides weights non-NULL. rescale logical; TRUE, normalise weights sum(weights) sum(exp(log_weights)) within block. Default: FALSE n_block integer; number conceptual blocks. needs specified larger max(block), keep output consistent size different inputs. values Vector blockwise aggregated log TRUE (default), return log-sum-exp. FALSE, return sum-exp. n_values supplied, used instead length(values) determine value vector input length. force_log FALSE (default), passes either weights log_weights , provided, log_weights taking precedence. TRUE, forces computation log_weights, whether given input .

title: Blockwise aggregation matrices — fm_block
text: (sparse) matrix

title: Blockwise aggregation matrices — fm_block
text: fm_block(): (sparse) matrix size n_block times length(block). fm_block_eval(): Evaluate aggregation. efficient alternative .vector(fm_block(...) %*% values). fm_block_logsumexp_eval(): Evaluate log-sum-exp aggregation. efficient numerically stable alternative log(.vector(fm_block(...) %*% exp(values))). fm_block_weights(): Computes (optionally) blockwise renormalised weights fm_block_log_weights(): Computes (optionally) blockwise renormalised log-weights fm_block_log_shift(): Computes shifts stable blocked log-sum-exp. compute \(\log(\sum_{; \text{block}_i=k} \exp(v_i) w_i)\) block k, first compute combined values weights, shift:   aggregate values within block:   implementation uses faster method:   fm_block_prep(): Helper function preparing block, weights, log_weights, n_block inputs.
code: w_values <- values + fm_block_log_weights(block, log_weights = log_weights) shift <- fm_block_log_shift(block, log_weights = w_values) agg <- aggregate(exp(w_values - shift[block]),                  by = list(block = block),                  \(x) log(sum(x))) agg$x <- agg$x + shift[agg$block] as.vector(   Matrix::sparseMatrix(     i = block,     j = rep(1L, length(block)),     x = exp(w_values - shift[block]),     dims = c(n_block, 1)) ) + shift

title: Blockwise aggregation matrices — fm_block

title: Check which mesh triangles are inside a polygon — fm_contains
code: if (TRUE &&   fm_safe_sp()) {   # Create a polygon and a mesh   obj <- sp::SpatialPolygons(     list(sp::Polygons(       list(sp::Polygon(rbind(         c(0, 0),         c(50, 0),         c(50, 50),         c(0, 50)       ))),       ID = 1     )),     proj4string = fm_CRS("longlat_globe")   )   mesh <- fm_rcdt_2d_inla(globe = 2, crs = fm_crs("sphere"))    ## 3 vertices found in the polygon   fm_contains(obj, mesh, type = "vertex")    ## 3 triangles found in the polygon   fm_contains(obj, mesh)    ## Multiple transformations can lead to slightly different results due to edge cases   ## 4 triangles found in the polygon   fm_contains(     obj,     fm_transform(mesh, crs = fm_crs("mollweide_norm"))   ) } #> Sparse geometry binary predicate list of length 1, where the predicate #> was `contains' #>  1: 7, 15, 18, 35

title: Obtain coordinate reference system object — fm_crs
text: Either sf::crs object fm_crs object, depending coordinate reference system described parameters can expressed pure crs object . crs object (sf::st_crs()) fm_crs object. S3 fm_crs object list elements crs oblique. fm_wkt_predef returns WKT2 string defining projection

title: Obtain coordinate reference system object — fm_crs
text: first two elements oblique vector (longitude, latitude) coordinates oblique centre point. third value (orientation) counter-clockwise rotation angle observer looking centre point outside sphere. fourth value quasi-longitude (orbit angle) rotation along oblique observers equator. Simple oblique: oblique=c(0, 45) Polar: oblique=c(0, 90) Quasi-transversal: oblique=c(0, 0, 90) Satellite orbit viewpoint: oblique=c(lon0-time*v1, 0, orbitangle, orbit0+time*v2), lon0 longitude satellite orbit crosses equator time=0, satellite angle orbit0 along orbit.  orbital angle relative equatorial plane orbitangle, v1 v2 angular velocities planet satellite, respectively. Note "forward" satellite's point view "right" projection. oblique[2] oblique[3] non-zero, resulting projection correct perfect spheres.

title: Methods for projecting to/from mesh objects — fm_evaluate
code: if (TRUE) {   n <- 20   loc <- matrix(runif(n * 2), n, 2)   mesh <- fm_rcdt_2d_inla(loc, refine = list(max.edge = 0.05))   proj <- fm_evaluator(mesh)   field <- cos(mesh$loc[, 1] * 2 * pi * 3) * sin(mesh$loc[, 2] * 2 * pi * 7)   image(proj$x, proj$y, fm_evaluate(proj, field)) }  # \donttest{ # if (require("ggplot2") && #  require("ggpolypath")) { #  ggplot() + #    gg(data = fm_as_sfc(mesh), col = field) # } # }

title: SPDE, GMRF, and Matérn process methods — fm_gmrf
text: x mesh object, e.g. fm_mesh_1d() fm_mesh_2d(). alpha SPDE operator order. resulting smoothness index nu = alpha - dim / 2. rho Matérn range parameter (scale parameter kappa = sqrt(8 * nu) / rho) sigma nominal Matérn std.dev. parameter n number samples generate loc locations evaluate random field, compatible fm_evaluate(x, loc = loc, field = ...) Q precision matrix A1, A2 Matrices, typically obtained fm_basis() /fm_block(). partial TRUE, compute partial inverse Q, .e. elements inverse corresponding non-zero pattern Q. (Note: can done efficiently Takahashi recursion method, avoid RcppEigen dependency currently disabled, slower method used efficient method reimplemented.) mu Optional mean vector constr Optional list constraint information, elements e. used small number exact constraints.

title: SPDE, GMRF, and Matérn process methods — fm_gmrf
text: fm_matern_sample() returns matrix, column sampled field. loc NULL, fm_dof(mesh) basis weights given. Otherwise, evaluated field nrow(loc) locations loc given.

title: SPDE, GMRF, and Matérn process methods — fm_gmrf
text: fm_matern_precision(): Construct (sparse) precision matrix basis weights Whittle-Matérn SPDE models.  boundary behaviour determined provided mesh function space. fm_matern_sample(): Simulate Matérn field given mesh covariance function parameters, optionally evaluate given locations. fm_covariance(): Compute covariance "A1 x" "A2 x", x basis vector precision matrix Q. fm_sample(): Generate n samples based sparse precision matrix Q

title: SPDE, GMRF, and Matérn process methods — fm_gmrf
code: library(Matrix) mesh <- fm_mesh_1d(-20:120, degree = 2) Q <- fm_matern_precision(mesh, alpha = 2, rho = 15, sigma = 1) x <- seq(0, 100, length.out = 601) A <- fm_basis(mesh, x) plot(x,   as.vector(Matrix::diag(fm_covariance(Q, A))),   type = "l",   ylab = "marginal variances" )   plot(x,   fm_evaluate(mesh, loc = x, field = fm_sample(1, Q)[, 1]),   type = "l",   ylab = "process sample" )

title: Multi-domain integration — fm_int
code: # Integration on the interval (2, 3.5) with Simpson's rule ips <- fm_int(fm_mesh_1d(0:4), samplers = cbind(2, 3.5)) plot(ips$x, ips$weight)   # Create integration points for the two intervals [0,3] and [5,10]  ips <- fm_int(   fm_mesh_1d(0:10),   matrix(c(0, 3, 5, 10), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) ) plot(ips$x, ips$weight)   # Convert a 1D mesh into integration points mesh <- fm_mesh_1d(seq(0, 10, by = 1)) ips <- fm_int(mesh, name = "time") plot(ips$time, ips$weight)   if (require("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   #' Integrate on a 2D mesh with polygon boundary subset   ips <- fm_int(fmexample$mesh, fmexample$boundary_sf[[1]])   ggplot() +     geom_sf(data = fm_as_sfc(fmexample$mesh, multi = TRUE), alpha = 0.5) +     geom_sf(data = fmexample$boundary_sf[[1]], fill = "red", alpha = 0.5) +     geom_sf(data = ips, aes(size = weight)) +     scale_size_area() }   ips <- fm_int(   fm_mesh_1d(0:10, boundary = "cyclic"),   rbind(c(0, 3), c(5, 10)) ) plot(ips$x, ips$weight)

Default equal convex preserveTopology logical; argument sf::st_simplify() dTolerance zero, controls dTolerance argument sf::st_simplify(). default pmin(convex, concave) / 40, chosen give approximately 4 subsegments per circular quadrant. crs Options crs object resulting polygon

title: Compute an extension of a spatial object — fm_nonconvex_hull
text: fm_nonconvex_hull() returns extended object sfc polygon object (regardless x class). fm_extensions() returns list sfc objects.

title: Compute an extension of a spatial object — fm_nonconvex_hull
text: Morphological dilation convex, followed closing concave, minimum concave curvature radius concave.  dilated set gaps width $$2 \text{convex} (\sqrt{1+2 \text{concave}/\text{convex}} - 1)$$ \(2\text{concave}\), minimum convex curvature radius convex. implementation based identity $$\text{dilation}() \& \text{closing}(b) = \text{dilation}(+b) \& \text{erosion}(b)$$ operations respect disks specified radii. convex, concave, dTolerance negative, fm_diameter * abs(...) used instead. Differs sf::st_buffer(x, convex) followed sf::st_concave_hull() (available GEOS 3.11) amount allowed concavity controlled.

code: geom_fm(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for fm_mesh_2d geom_fm(   mapping = NULL,   data = NULL,   mapping_int = NULL,   mapping_bnd = NULL,   defs_int = NULL,   defs_bnd = NULL,   ...,   crs = NULL )  # S3 method for fm_segm geom_fm(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, ..., crs = NULL)  # S3 method for fm_mesh_1d geom_fm(   mapping = NULL,   data = NULL,   ...,   xlim = NULL,   basis = TRUE,   knots = TRUE,   derivatives = FALSE,   weights = NULL )

title: ggplot2 geomes for fmesher related objects — geom_fm
text: mapping object generate geom. data object generate geom. ... Arguments passed geom method. mapping_int aes interior constraint edges. mapping_bnd aes boundary edges. defs_int additional settings interior constraint edges. defs_bnd additional settings boundary edges. crs Optional crs transform object plotting. xlim numeric 2-vector; specifies interval compute functions. Default data$interval basis logical; TRUE (default), show spline basis functions knots logical; TRUE (default), show spline knot locations derivatives logical; TRUE (default), draw first order derivatives instead function values weights numeric vector; provided, draw weighted basis functions resulting weighted sum.

title: ggplot2 geomes for fmesher related objects — geom_fm
text: combination ggplot2 geoms.

text: geom_fm(fm_mesh_2d): Converts fm_mesh_2d() object sf fm_as_sfc() uses geom_sf visualize triangles edges. geom_fm(fm_segm): Converts fm_segm() object sf fm_as_sfc() uses geom_sf visualize . geom_fm(fm_mesh_1d): Evaluates plots basis functions defined fm_mesh_1d() object.

title: ggplot2 geomes for fmesher related objects — geom_fm
code: if (require("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   ggplot() +     geom_fm(data = fmexample$mesh) }   if (require("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   m <- fm_mesh_2d(     cbind(10, 20),     boundary = fm_extensions(cbind(10, 20), c(25, 65)),     max.edge = c(2, 5),     crs = fm_crs("+proj=longlat")   )   print(ggplot() +     geom_fm(data = m))   print(ggplot() +     geom_fm(data = m, crs = fm_crs("epsg:27700"))) }   # \donttest{ if (require("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   # Compute a mesh vertex based function on a different grid   px <- fm_pixels(fm_transform(m, fm_crs("mollweide_globe")))   px$fun <- fm_evaluate(m,     loc = px,     field = sin(m$loc[, 1] / 5) * sin(m$loc[, 2] / 5)   )   print(ggplot() +     geom_tile(aes(geometry = geometry, fill = fun),       data = px,       stat = "sf_coordinates"     ) +     geom_fm(       data = m, alpha = 0.2, linewidth = 0.05,       crs = fm_crs("mollweide_globe")     )) }  # } if (require("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   m <- fm_mesh_1d(c(1, 2, 4, 6, 10), boundary = c("n", "d"), degree = 2)   ggplot() +     geom_fm(data = m, weights = c(4, 2, 4, -1)) }   if (require("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   m <- fm_mesh_1d(     c(1, 2, 3, 5, 7),     boundary = c("dirichlet", "neumann"),     degree = 2   )   print(ggplot() +     geom_fm(data = m)) }

title: fmesher 0.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-08-18 Simplify LICENSE information R package DESCRIPTION Fix example legacy plot_PolySet method Fix C++ unused-variable warning detected clang-tidy version 16.0.6 Add workaround sf::st_buffer supporting negative distance s2 longlat coordinates. Fixes #5

title: fmesher 0.1.0
text: Full conversion fmesher interface standalone binary R-INLA (https://www.r-inla.org) interface powered Rcpp (https://cran.r-project.org/package=Rcpp) Tools 2D 1D function spaces, see fm_mesh_2d() fm_mesh_1d() Tools CRS handling see fm_crs() fm_transform() Plotting support base graphics, rgl, ggplot2 Added basic GMRF tools, see fm_matern_precision()
